title-group.article-title: Virtual Instrument Cluster for enhancing the configurability of an automotive simulator

contrib-group.aff: Department of Applied Mechanics, Centro de Estudios e Investigaciones Técnicas de Gipuzkoa (CEIT), Spain

abstract.p: Automotive simulators are an important tool when developing and validating new vehicle functions and devices. Thereby, configurability is an essential requirement for simulators that are used in the field of research. The growing number of new systems makes it imperative to reduce their time to market to a minimum. Furthermore, full digital instrument clusters are becoming more common inside consumer vehicles today. They erase the traditional limitations of analog dashboards and enable the design of intuitive and efficient solutions, for instance, by integrating various onboard devices in one central human–machine interface (HMI). Naturally, this generates new challenges in the human-in-the-loop model of validation. Driven by these demands, a new architecture is proposed that allows a complete (but easy) reconfiguration of a driving simulator, in particular, at the front end (the HMI). The core element is a Virtual Instrument Cluster consisting of a personal computer and a high-resolution thin film transistor (TFT) screen. Focusing on the interaction between the driver and the simulator, the objective is to facilitate the integration of new systems and designs into a realistic environment. To show the potential of the Virtual Instrument Cluster, this paper presents three practical examples to demonstrate the capability, usability, validity and adaptivity to new systems.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Ainara Bilbao received her MS in Automatic and Industrial Electronic Engineering from the University of Mondragon, Gipuzkoa, Spain. Currently, she is a Ph.D. student and junior researcher at CEIT (Centro de Estudios e Investigaciones Técnicas, San Sebastián, Spain), where she is working in the ITS and Simulators Area, at the Applied Mechanics department. Her areas of expertise are related to Intelligent Transportation Systems, automotive simulators and automotive communication protocols. In the past she worked as electronic laboratory coordinator at the Innovation Department of Copreci S. Coop. in Aretxabaleta, Spain.

Alfonso Brazález obtained a PhD degree in Physics from the University of Navarra. Before, he received a Bachelor’s Degree in Physics from the University of the Basque Country (UPV-EHU) and a Master’s degree in Electronics and Control from the same University. Currently he is the coordinator of the Simulators and ITS group in the Applied Mechanics Department at CEIT (Centro de Estudios e Investigaciones Técnicas, San Sebastián, Spain). His areas of expertise are related to Modelling and Simulation. Apart from those areas, his current main research lines are connected to Intelligent Transportation Systems, focusing on the development of new Advanced Driving Assistance Systems, combining simulation with real developments. He has collaborated on and coordinated numerous projects and he has numerous publications in national and international conferences and indexed journals and one utility model patent. He is part of the Spanish M2F (Moves to Future) Platform, the Spanish eSafety forum and he participates in several EARPA (European Automotive Research Partners Association) Task Forces.

Iñigo García received his MS in Computer Science from the University of the Basque Country (UPV-EHU). Currently, he is a Ph.D. student at CEIT (Centro de Estudios e Investigaciones Técnicas, San Sebastián, Spain), where he is working in the ITS and Simulators Area, at the Applied Mechanics department. His main research area is Intelligent Transportation Systems in general, but his work is oriented towards Human Machine Interface (HMI). He is also interested in everything related to Artificial Intelligence.

Michael Tybel received his Master of Science Degree in IT-Automotive from the University of Applied Science in Bochum (Germany). Currently, he is a product manager for Automotive Test-Systems at Scienlab Electronic Systems in Bochum, Germany. In the past he worked as junior researcher at the ITS department at CEIT Centro de Estudios e Investigaciones Técnicas, San Sebastián, Spain).

Nerea Aguriano received her MS in Telecommunications Engineering from the School of Engineering at the University of Navarra, Spain, in 2007. Currently, she is a Ph.D. student and junior researcher at CEIT (Centro de Estudios e Investigaciones Técnicas, San Sebastián, Spain), where she is working in the ITS and Simulators Area, at the Applied Mechanics department. Her main research area is Intelligent Transportation Systems and intelligent decision systems.
